Abstract
In this note we show that k-convex functions on Rn are twice differentiable almost everywhere
for every positive integer k > n/2. This generalizes the classical Alexsandrov's theorem for
convex functions.

1

Introduction

A classical result of Alexsandrov [1] asserts that convex functions in Rn are
twice differentiable a.e., (see also [3], [8] for more modern treatments). It is
well known that Sobolev functions u ∈ W 2,p , for p > n/2 are twice differentiable a.e.. The following weaker notion of convexity known as k-convexity
was introduced by Trudinger and Wang [12, 13]. Let Ω ⊂ Rn be an open set
and C 2 (Ω) be the class of continuously twice differentiable functions on Ω.
For k = 1, 2, . . . , n and a function u ∈ C 2 (Ω), the k-Hessian operator, Fk , is

we adopt a viscosity definition as in [13]. An upper semi-continuous function

for which the difference u−q has a finite local maximum in Ω. Henceforth, we

above definition is equivalent to the usual definition of subharmonic function,

k = 1, 2, . . . , n, and a function u ∈ Φn (Ω) if and only if it is convex on each
